title: Cross-Text Connections
subtitle: Analyzing Relationships Between Texts
learning_objectives: The Core: Master analyzing how paired texts relate to each other
The Skill: Identify relationship types—agreement, disagreement, complement, build, qualify
The Problem: Distinguish nuanced relationships from simple agree/disagree
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase RELATE Strategy for 100% provable text relationships

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Identify nuanced connections, not just agree/disagree

content.heading: PHASE 1: Compare Topics and Angles
content.subtitle: What Is Each Text Actually About?

core_principle.title: Foundation: Same Topic, Different Angles
core_principle.description: Cross-text questions pair passages on the same general topic. Understanding what SPECIFIC angle each takes is the foundation for identifying their relationship.

strategy_steps.title: Identify Shared Topic
strategy_steps.description: What general subject do both texts address?

examples.passage_1: AI tutoring systems improve math scores
examples.passage_2: Risks of AI in education (reduced interaction, privacy)

strategy_steps.title: Identify Each Text's Specific Angle
strategy_steps.description: What particular aspect or perspective does each text focus on?

strategy_steps.title: Note Each Text's Position/Claim
strategy_steps.description: What is each author arguing or explaining?

example.text_1: Physical books provide better comprehension (argues benefit)
example.text_2: Digital books offer accessibility advantages (argues different benefit)

text_1.angle: Food security solution for growing cities
text_1.position: Vertical farming addresses urban food challenges
text_1.key_points: Year-round production, 390x more food per sq ft, reduces transportation

text_2.position: High initial costs limit widespread adoption
text_2.key_points: Substantial setup costs, energy expenses, limited to high-value crops

worked_example.relationship_preview: Complementary but with tension—both focus on vertical farming, one emphasizes potential, other emphasizes barriers

core_principle.title: Position = Author's Core Argument or Explanation
core_principle.description: Before identifying relationships, clarify exactly what each author is saying. Position includes both the claim and the reasoning/evidence.

position_mapping.description: The central point author wants to make

position_mapping.example: Text 1: 20% better recall with print, tactile experience aids learning

position_mapping.description: How broad or limited is the claim?
examples: Qualified: 'Physical books show advantages in comprehension'
Conditional: 'Physical books benefit certain types of reading'

position_mapping.description: How definitive or tentative is the author?
position_mapping.spectrum: Strongly advocating → Presenting balanced view → Raising questions

template.overlap: [Do they address same aspects or different?]

text_1_position.claim: Physical books provide better comprehension and retention
text_1_position.tone: Advocates for physical books based on research

text_2_position.claim: Digital books offer practical advantages that outweigh comprehension differences
text_2_position.evidence: Accessibility features, environmental benefits, cost-effectiveness, comprehension gap decreases with practice
text_2_position.scope: Acknowledges Text 1's points but argues other factors more important
text_2_position.tone: Balanced view favoring digital for practical reasons

worked_example.relationship: Nuanced disagreement—Text 2 ACKNOWLEDGES Text 1's comprehension point but argues other factors outweigh it

elements.reveal: Texts rarely completely agree or completely disagree. Most relationships are nuanced—one acknowledges the other's points but emphasizes different aspects or draws different conclusions.

relationship_types.definition: Both texts support same conclusion with similar or different evidence
relationship_types.structure: Text 1: Claims X with evidence A. Text 2: Also claims X with evidence B.

example.text_1: Urban gardens reduce crime (data from Detroit)
example.text_2: Urban gardens reduce crime (data from Philadelphia)
example.relationship: Both support same claim with independent evidence

relationship_types.definition: Texts focus on different dimensions of same topic without contradicting
relationship_types.common_on_sat: Very common—tests ability to see how texts work together
relationship_types.structure: Text 1: Addresses aspect A. Text 2: Addresses aspect B. Both contribute to understanding topic.

example.text_1: Urban gardens provide crime reduction benefits
example.text_2: Urban gardens provide nutrition and health benefits
example.relationship: Complementary—different benefits, both support value of urban gardens

relationship_types.signal: Neither contradicts the other; each adds unique piece

relationship_types.definition: One text agrees with another but adds conditions, limitations, or complexity
relationship_types.structure: Text 1: Makes claim X. Text 2: Agrees X is true BUT adds important qualifications.

example.text_2: Homework benefits exist BUT vary by age—effective for high school, minimal for elementary
example.relationship: Text 2 doesn't reject Text 1 but adds crucial 'when/where' conditions

relationship_types.key_words: While generally true, depends on, varies by, with the caveat

relationship_types.definition: Text acknowledges some points from other but emphasizes different conclusion
relationship_types.most_common_on_sat: This is the SAT's favorite—tests nuanced thinking
relationship_types.structure: Text 1: Claims X. Text 2: Acknowledges X has merit BUT argues Y is more important or Y counterbalances X.

example.text_1: AI tutoring improves learning outcomes (30% better math scores)
example.text_2: While AI shows benefits, risks include reduced human interaction, privacy concerns, over-dependence
example.relationship: Text 2 doesn't deny benefits but presents important counterbalancing concerns

relationship_types.key_distinction: NOT complete disagreement—Text 2 acknowledges Text 1's points while adding critical balance

relationship_types.definition: Texts reach opposite conclusions or contradict each other's core claims
relationship_types.rare_on_sat: Less common—most relationships are more nuanced
relationship_types.structure: Text 1: Claims X. Text 2: Directly contradicts, claiming NOT X.

example.text_2: Remote work decreases productivity across all job types
example.note: True disagreement would involve direct contradiction, not just different emphasis

questions.q: Do texts reach same or opposite conclusions?
Do texts address same aspects or different aspects?
Does one text acknowledge the other's points?
questions.yes: Likely qualified agreement or partial disagreement
questions.no: Check if truly independent or actually contrasting

questions.q: Does one text add 'but,' 'however,' or conditions?

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage_1: AI tutoring systems can provide personalized learning experiences, adapting to individual student needs and providing instant feedback. Research shows 30% improvement in math scores when students use AI tutors consistently.
content.passage_2: While AI tutoring shows promise, it raises concerns about reduced human interaction in education, student data privacy, and the risk of students becoming over-dependent on technology for learning.
content.question: Which best describes how Passage 2 relates to Passage 1?

walkthrough.question: What is the shared topic and each text's angle?
walkthrough.answer: Topic: AI in education | Text 1 angle: Benefits/effectiveness | Text 2 angle: Risks/concerns
walkthrough.reasoning: Both discuss AI tutoring but from different perspectives

walkthrough.question: Map each text's position
walkthrough.text_1_position: AI tutoring provides benefits (personalization, feedback) with proven results (30% improvement)
walkthrough.text_2_position: AI tutoring has promise ('while...shows promise') BUT presents important concerns (interaction, privacy, dependence)
walkthrough.key_observation: Text 2 ACKNOWLEDGES benefits ('shows promise') but emphasizes risks

options_analysis.text: Passage 2 completely contradicts Passage 1's claims about AI effectiveness
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ WRONG—Text 2 acknowledges promise/benefits, doesn't contradict the 30% improvement claim

options_analysis.text: Passage 2 provides additional evidence supporting Passage 1's arguments
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ WRONG—Text 2 doesn't provide supporting evidence; it raises concerns/counterpoints

options_analysis.text: Passage 2 presents important concerns that balance Passage 1's optimistic view
options_analysis.analysis: ✓ CORRECT—PARTIAL DISAGREEMENT/COUNTERBALANCE type: Text 2 acknowledges benefits but presents counterbalancing concerns (human interaction, privacy, dependence)

options_analysis.text: Passage 2 discusses an entirely different aspect of AI that doesn't relate to Passage 1
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ WRONG—Both discuss AI tutoring; Text 2 directly addresses implications of what Text 1 describes

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the RELATE Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Compare Topics → Outline Positions → Navigate Relationships
content.passage_1: Urban gardens significantly benefit communities by reducing crime rates. Research in Detroit found neighborhoods with community gardens saw 40% reduction in crime, creating safer environments for families.
content.passage_2: Community gardens build social connections and provide fresh food access to urban residents. Participants report stronger neighborhood bonds and 78% improvement in household nutrition.
content.question: How do these passages relate?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: What's each text's angle? Phase 2: What does each claim? Phase 3: Same conclusion? Different aspects? Acknowledge each other?

options: Passage 2 contradicts Passage 1's claims about urban gardens
Passage 2 provides different evidence supporting the overall benefits of urban gardens
Passage 2 proves that Passage 1's data about crime is incorrect
The passages discuss completely unrelated aspects of urban gardens
content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1—Topics and angles:
Shared topic: Urban gardens' value
Text 1 angle: Safety/crime reduction benefits
Text 2 angle: Social connection and nutrition benefits

PHASE 2—Positions:
Text 1: Urban gardens reduce crime (40% reduction data)
Text 2: Urban gardens build community and improve nutrition (social bonds, 78% improvement)
Neither contradicts the other—different aspects

PHASE 3—Relationship type:

A: ✗ WRONG—No contradiction. Text 2 doesn't address crime at all, so can't contradict Text 1's crime claims

B: ✓ CORRECT—COMPLEMENTARY relationship: Both support value of urban gardens but focus on different benefits (safety vs. social/health). Different evidence (crime data vs. nutrition data) supporting overarching conclusion that urban gardens benefit communities

C: ✗ WRONG—Text 2 doesn't discuss crime data, so can't prove it incorrect

D: ✗ WRONG—Both relate to urban gardens' community benefits, just different dimensions. They're related and complementary, not unrelated

content.heading: Master These Patterns—Identify Relationships Instantly

rows: Both texts argue X is beneficial with different evidence
Text 1: crime benefits, Text 2: health benefits
While generally true, depends on, varies by
Text 1: X is effective; Text 2: X effective BUT varies by age
While X shows promise, however, raises concerns
Text 1: benefits; Text 2: acknowledges benefits BUT emphasizes risks
Text 1: X increases Y; Text 2: X decreases Y

content.expert_insight: SAT favors nuanced relationships—complementary and partial disagreement are most common. Avoid seeing only complete agreement or complete disagreement.

content.heading: Cross-Text Connection Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Compare topics and identify each text's specific angle—what aspect each focuses on
Phase 2: Outline each text's position—claim, evidence, scope, and tone
Phase 3: Navigate relationship type—most are complementary or partial disagreement, not complete agree/disagree
The 100% Rule: Focus on HOW texts relate, not just what each says individually. Nuanced relationships are most common.
content.strategy_reminder: Remember RELATE: Read both passages, Examine each angle, List positions clearly, Assess overlap and tension, Test relationship type, Eliminate oversimplified options
content.expert_insight: Common traps: (1) Seeing only complete agreement/disagreement when relationship is nuanced, (2) Missing complementary relationships, (3) Analyzing texts separately instead of their relationship.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question: Passage 1 argues that urban gardens increase property values by 10% and reduce crime. Passage 2 discusses how urban gardens build community connections and provide fresh food access. How do these passages relate?
options: Passage 2 contradicts Passage 1's claims about urban gardens
Passage 2 provides different evidence supporting the overall benefits of urban gardens
Passage 2 proves that Passage 1's data about property values is incorrect
The passages discuss completely unrelated aspects of urban gardens
slides.explanation:
Phase analysis:

PHASE 1—Topics and angles:
Shared topic: Urban gardens
Passage 1 angle: Economic and safety benefits (property values, crime)
Passage 2 angle: Social and health benefits (community, food access)

PHASE 2—Positions:
Passage 1 position: Urban gardens provide economic/safety value (10% property increase, crime reduction)
Passage 2 position: Urban gardens provide social/health value (community bonds, nutrition access)
No contradiction—different dimensions of benefits

PHASE 3—Relationship:

A: ✗ WRONG—No contradiction. Passage 2 doesn't address property values or crime, so can't contradict those claims

B: ✓ CORRECT—COMPLEMENTARY relationship: Both support value of urban gardens with different evidence. Passage 1 provides economic/safety evidence, Passage 2 provides social/health evidence. Together they create fuller picture of benefits.

C: ✗ WRONG—Passage 2 doesn't mention property values, so can't prove data incorrect

D: ✗ WRONG—Both discuss urban gardens' community benefits, just different types. Related and complementary, not unrelated.

strategy_card.title: The RELATE Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Check if positions acknowledge each other
Complete Agreement: Same conclusion, similar/different evidence
Qualified Agreement: Agrees but adds conditions

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Most relationships are nuanced—complementary or partial disagreement. Avoid oversimplifying to complete agree/disagree.

common_mistakes: Seeing only complete agreement or complete disagreement
Missing complementary relationships where texts address different aspects
Analyzing each text separately instead of their relationship
Ignoring acknowledgments one text makes of another's points

relationship_quick_reference.Most Common: Complementary (different aspects) or Partial Disagreement (acknowledges but counterbalances)
relationship_quick_reference.Complementary: Different dimensions, both support broader conclusion
relationship_quick_reference.Partial Disagreement: Text 2 acknowledges Text 1's points BUT emphasizes concerns/alternatives
relationship_quick_reference.Key Test: Does one text acknowledge the other's points? If yes → likely qualified or partial, not complete disagree

strategy_integration.key_innovation: 3-Phase RELATE Strategy: Compare Topics → Outline Positions → Navigate Relationships
